@martinvars The point (mainly for #Bitcoin) is that the supply and economics are pre-determined and guaranteed with code, so yes there‚Äôs volatility now but no one can mess with the ‚Äúphysics‚Äù of the underlying asset, and that to me has a ton of value. Savings only go one way with fiatüîª

Much has been said about inflation (now 7.5%, but likely higher). It turns out that when you print non-stop & ignore supply chain issues, it becomes a thing ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Now that we‚Äôre here though, inflation with growth is likely better than a recession. Don‚Äôt mess it up both ways please.
@agarwal @zack @asuth @GrowSF That‚Äôs the only way indeed. Thanks for doing the hard, right work.

@mr_pixelr @EmSheDoesIt I hope you‚Äôre right. It would be great. But that wasn‚Äôt my point. No matter how many hours you work a day, we still spend a considerable % of our lives working. Doing it alone/virtually and not having as many irl experiences is what I was talking about.
@zack @asuth The only path is a change of leadership and ideology. That means voting in people with common sense and a desire to work hard to address these issues at their core.

@zack @asuth I know you‚Äôre coming from a very good place with this OpEd. I felt that way years ago, joined Tipping Point, and have come to the realization that no amount of money or skilled time spent on these issues can outweigh the absurd policies wreaking havoc across the Bay Area.
@karengeier Sure. If you can be productive while walking your dog in a park, enjoy it fully.

@EmSheDoesIt I think it‚Äôs a false dichotomy. You can‚Äôt spend all your day with friends unless you do nothing. We spend 8+ hours a day focused on work. Being alone at home in front of a screen, vs. interacting with other humans irl is what I‚Äôm talking about.

@the_blueprint I probably did the kind of work you can‚Äôt even imagine, including sleeping on the floor of my office while building my startups. Have you tried that? Not very comfortable. That idea that work is horrible unless you‚Äôve already made it is comically nonsensical.
@RuthKapelus All part of life! Although microwaving fish‚Ä¶ won‚Äôt be missed.

@ideafaktory I hope you‚Äôre right, but I worry about geographic inadequacy of talent pools. Not sure you‚Äôll be able to build competitive companies based on living preferences vs. these who will focus on finding the best talent irrespective of location.
@michaelperry Totally. It would be great to find a better balance. Hybrid is way harder to figure out vs. in person or fully remote, though.

It just hit me that a good chunk of this next generation coming into the workforce might never experience the joys of collaborating with colleagues in a vibrant workplace, sharing coffee, after work drinks, ‚Ä¶ Sad to imagine so many people looking at screens all day.

I now look forward to having more free time in the months to come before I start building something new and exciting again. Onward! (7/7)

I‚Äôm incredibly grateful to Mark for the opportunity and privilege to share a bit of the journey over the years. I‚Äôll keep lifelong memories and friendships from my time at the company, and I wish it well in the years to come. (6/7)

I‚Äôll keep a special place in my heart for some of the most fun and stimulating years of my life building Messenger with so many talented people. In turn, the Novi years were the most mission-driven and intellectually stimulating ones. (5/7)

I find comfort and confidence in knowing that they will continue to execute our important mission well under @skasriel‚Äôs leadership, and I can‚Äôt wait to witness this from the outside. I know there‚Äôs greatness ahead. (4/7)

The one thing I‚Äôm the proudest of during my time here is the amazing kickass team we‚Äôve assembled over the last three years. This is the most resilient, passionate, determined and talented group of humans I‚Äôve ever worked with. (3/7)

While there‚Äôs still so much to do right on the heels of launching Novi ‚Äî and I remain as passionate as ever about the need for change in our payments and financial systems ‚Äî my entrepreneurial DNA has been nudging me for too many mornings in a row to continue ignoring it. (2/7)
Personal news: after a fulfilling seven years at Meta, I‚Äôve made the difficult decision to step down and leave the company at the end of this year. (1/7)
